description: Framework agreement for professional and consulting services with Statement of Work structure

clauses.title: Payment Terms
clauses.plainDescription: How quickly must the client pay invoices after receipt?
clauses.legalContext: Payment terms affect cash flow for both parties. Longer terms benefit clients; shorter terms benefit providers. Industry standard ranges from Net 15 to Net 60.

options.label: Net 15 Days
options.plainDescription: Client must pay invoices within 15 days of receipt. Fast payment improves provider cash flow.
options.legalText: Client shall pay all undisputed invoices within fifteen (15) days of the invoice date.

options.label: Net 30 Days
options.plainDescription: Client must pay invoices within 30 days - the most common business standard.
options.legalText: Client shall pay all undisputed invoices within thirty (30) days of the invoice date.

options.label: Net 45 Days
options.plainDescription: Client has 45 days to pay invoices, providing extended payment flexibility.
prosPartyA: May be required for enterprise clients
options.legalText: Client shall pay all undisputed invoices within forty-five (45) days of the invoice date.

options.label: Net 60 Days
options.plainDescription: Client has 60 days to pay invoices - maximum flexibility for client, longer wait for provider.
options.legalText: Client shall pay all undisputed invoices within sixty (60) days of the invoice date.

clauses.title: Work Product IP Ownership
clauses.plainDescription: Who owns the intellectual property in work created by the provider specifically for this engagement?
clauses.legalContext: IP ownership is often the most negotiated MSA provision. Work-for-hire gives clients full ownership; provider-owns-with-license gives providers reuse rights. This affects pricing and provider business models.

options.label: Client Owns All Work Product
options.plainDescription: Client owns all intellectual property in work created specifically for them. Provider assigns all rights to client.
consPartyB: May pay premium for full ownership
options.legalText: All Work Product created by Provider specifically for Client shall be owned by Client. Provider hereby assigns to Client all right, title, and interest in such Work Product, including all intellectual property rights.

options.label: Provider Owns, Client Gets License
options.plainDescription: Provider retains ownership but grants client a perpetual, royalty-free license to use the work for internal business purposes.
options.legalText: Provider retains all right, title, and interest in the Work Product. Provider grants Client a non-exclusive, perpetual, worldwide, royalty-free license to use, copy, and modify the Work Product for Client's internal business purposes.

options.label: Joint Ownership
options.plainDescription: Both parties jointly own the work product and can each use, license, or exploit it independently.
options.legalText: The Parties shall jointly own the Work Product. Each Party may use, license, and exploit the Work Product without accounting to the other, subject to the confidentiality obligations herein.

clauses.title: Limitation of Liability
clauses.plainDescription: What is the maximum liability each party can face for breaches of this agreement?
clauses.legalContext: Liability caps allocate risk between parties. Higher caps protect the injured party but increase risk exposure. Caps are typically tied to fees paid.

options.label: 12 Months of Fees
options.plainDescription: Each party's liability capped at fees paid in the 12 months before the claim arose.
options.legalText: Each Party's total aggregate liability under this Agreement shall not exceed the fees paid or payable by Client in the twelve (12) months preceding the claim.

options.label: Fees Under Applicable SOW
options.plainDescription: Liability capped at fees paid under the specific Statement of Work that gave rise to the claim.
prosPartyB: May limit recovery for cross-SOW issues
options.legalText: Each Party's total aggregate liability for claims arising from a particular Statement of Work shall not exceed the fees paid or payable under that Statement of Work.

options.label: 2x Annual Fees
options.plainDescription: Liability capped at twice the annual fees, providing greater protection for significant damages.
options.legalText: Each Party's total aggregate liability under this Agreement shall not exceed two times (2x) the fees paid or payable by Client in the twelve (12) months preceding the claim.

clauses.title: Termination for Convenience
clauses.plainDescription: Can either party end the agreement without cause, and with what notice period?
clauses.legalContext: Termination for convenience gives flexibility to exit the relationship. The question is whether it's mutual, one-sided, and what notice period applies.

options.label: No Termination for Convenience
options.plainDescription: Neither party can terminate without cause. Agreement continues for full term or until material breach.
options.legalText: Neither Party may terminate this Agreement for convenience. This Agreement may only be terminated for cause in accordance with Section [X].

options.label: Mutual with 30 Days Notice
options.plainDescription: Either party can terminate the agreement with 30 days written notice, without needing to show cause.
options.legalText: Either Party may terminate this Agreement for convenience upon thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the other Party.

options.label: Mutual with 60 Days Notice
options.plainDescription: Either party can terminate with 60 days written notice, allowing more transition time.
options.legalText: Either Party may terminate this Agreement for convenience upon sixty (60) days' prior written notice to the other Party.

clauses.title: Warranty Period for Deliverables
clauses.plainDescription: How long does the provider warrant that deliverables will work as specified after delivery?
clauses.legalContext: Warranty periods give clients time to identify defects. Longer warranties benefit clients; shorter warranties reduce provider risk. 30-90 days is typical.

options.label: 30 Days
options.plainDescription: Provider warrants deliverables for 30 days following delivery or acceptance.
options.legalText: Provider warrants that Deliverables will substantially conform to specifications for thirty (30) days following delivery or acceptance, whichever is later.

options.label: 60 Days
options.plainDescription: Provider warrants deliverables for 60 days - a balanced standard warranty period.
options.legalText: Provider warrants that Deliverables will substantially conform to specifications for sixty (60) days following delivery or acceptance, whichever is later.

options.label: 90 Days
options.plainDescription: Provider warrants deliverables for 90 days, providing extended protection for the client.
options.legalText: Provider warrants that Deliverables will substantially conform to specifications for ninety (90) days following delivery or acceptance, whichever is later.

clauses.title: Indemnification Scope
clauses.plainDescription: What claims must each party defend the other against, and how broad is the protection?
clauses.legalContext: Indemnification transfers risk for third-party claims. Broader indemnification benefits the protected party but increases risk for the indemnifying party.

options.label: IP Infringement Only
options.plainDescription: Provider indemnifies client only for third-party IP infringement claims related to deliverables.
options.legalText: Provider shall indemnify Client against third-party claims that the Deliverables infringe any patent, copyright, trademark, or trade secret.

options.label: Standard Mutual (IP + Negligence)
options.plainDescription: Each party indemnifies the other for IP infringement, gross negligence, and confidentiality breaches.
options.legalText: Each Party shall indemnify the other against third-party claims arising from: (a) infringement of intellectual property rights; (b) gross negligence or willful misconduct; and (c) breach of confidentiality obligations.

options.label: Broad Provider Indemnification
options.plainDescription: Provider broadly indemnifies client for IP infringement, negligence, confidentiality breaches, and compliance violations.
options.legalText: Provider shall indemnify Client against third-party claims arising from: (a) IP infringement; (b) Provider's negligence; (c) confidentiality breaches; (d) Provider's violation of applicable laws; and (e) Provider's acts or omissions in performing the Services.

clauses.title: Confidentiality Duration
clauses.plainDescription: How long do confidentiality obligations last after the agreement ends?
clauses.legalContext: Confidentiality obligations often survive the agreement. Longer periods protect information but extend obligations. Trade secrets warrant indefinite protection.

options.label: 3 Years After Termination
options.plainDescription: Confidentiality obligations survive for 3 years after the agreement ends.
options.legalText: Confidentiality obligations shall survive termination of this Agreement for three (3) years, except for trade secrets which shall be protected indefinitely.

options.label: 5 Years After Termination
options.plainDescription: Confidentiality obligations survive for 5 years, providing extended protection.
options.legalText: Confidentiality obligations shall survive termination of this Agreement for five (5) years, except for trade secrets which shall be protected indefinitely.

options.label: Perpetual
options.plainDescription: Confidentiality obligations continue indefinitely for all confidential information.
options.legalText: Confidentiality obligations shall survive termination of this Agreement indefinitely.

clauses.title: Insurance Requirements
clauses.plainDescription: What insurance must the provider maintain throughout the engagement?
clauses.legalContext: Insurance requirements ensure providers can cover potential claims. Higher requirements provide more protection but may limit provider options or increase costs.

options.label: Standard ($1M/$2M)
options.plainDescription: Provider maintains $1M per occurrence / $2M aggregate general liability and $1M professional liability.
consPartyB: May want higher limits for large projects
options.legalText: Provider shall maintain: (a) Commercial General Liability: $1,000,000 per occurrence, $2,000,000 aggregate; (b) Professional Liability: $1,000,000 per claim.

options.label: Enhanced ($2M/$5M)
options.plainDescription: Provider maintains $2M per occurrence / $5M aggregate general liability and $2M professional liability.
options.legalText: Provider shall maintain: (a) Commercial General Liability: $2,000,000 per occurrence, $5,000,000 aggregate; (b) Professional Liability: $2,000,000 per claim.

options.label: Basic (No Minimum)
options.plainDescription: Provider maintains commercially reasonable insurance with no specific minimums required.
options.legalText: Provider shall maintain commercially reasonable insurance coverage appropriate for the Services, including general liability and professional liability insurance.

clauses.title: Change Order Process
clauses.plainDescription: How are scope changes to Statements of Work handled and approved?
clauses.legalContext: Change orders manage scope creep and ensure both parties agree on adjustments. Formal processes protect both parties but add administrative overhead.

options.label: Formal Written Change Orders
options.plainDescription: All scope changes require a formal written change order signed by both parties before work begins.
options.legalText: No change to scope is binding unless documented in a written change order signed by authorized representatives of both Parties, specifying the scope change, fee adjustment, and timeline impact.

options.label: Email Approval Acceptable
options.plainDescription: Scope changes can be approved via email from authorized representatives, then documented.
options.legalText: Scope changes may be approved via email from authorized representatives, followed by documentation in a written change order within five (5) business days.

options.label: Threshold-Based (Small Changes Informal)
options.plainDescription: Small changes (under a threshold) can be approved informally; larger changes require formal change orders.
options.legalText: Changes with impact under $5,000 or 5% of SOW value may be approved via email. Changes exceeding this threshold require a formal written change order signed by both Parties.

clauses.title: Non-Compete / Non-Circumvention
clauses.plainDescription: Are there restrictions on the provider working with the client's competitors or clients?
clauses.legalContext: Non-compete provisions restrict provider's business. California Business & Professions Code 16600 makes most non-competes unenforceable. Non-circumvention (protecting customer relationships) may be treated differently than non-compete provisions.

options.label: No Restrictions
options.plainDescription: Provider has no restrictions on working with client's competitors or clients.
options.legalText: [No non-compete or non-circumvention provisions]

CALIFORNIA.note: Recommended for California - avoids unenforceable non-compete provisions

options.label: Non-Circumvention Only
options.plainDescription: Provider cannot directly solicit or contract with client's customers discovered through the engagement.
options.legalText: During the term and for one (1) year thereafter, Provider shall not directly solicit or contract with any customer or prospect of Client that Provider became aware of solely through this engagement, without Client's prior written consent.

CALIFORNIA.warning: Non-circumvention provisions may be analyzed under California's non-compete laws. Courts may scrutinize provisions that effectively prevent the provider from engaging in their trade.

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Generally enforceable if limited to genuinely protectable interests

SPAIN.note: Subject to reasonableness review under Spanish commercial law

options.label: Full Non-Compete (During Term)
options.plainDescription: Provider cannot work with named competitors during the agreement term. Restrictions end at termination.
options.legalText: During the term of this Agreement, Provider shall not provide substantially similar services to the following competitors: [NAMED COMPETITORS]. This restriction does not survive termination.

CALIFORNIA.warning: Non-compete provisions are void and unenforceable in California under Business & Professions Code 16600. Select 'No Restrictions' instead.

ENGLAND_WALES.note: Enforceable if reasonable in duration and scope - courts may modify excessive restrictions

SPAIN.note: May require compensation to the restricted party under Spanish law

clauses.title: Dispute Resolution
clauses.plainDescription: How and where will disputes about this agreement be resolved? You can choose courts in the governing law jurisdiction, courts elsewhere, or private arbitration.
clauses.legalContext: For services disputes, the choice of forum can significantly impact cost and convenience. Arbitration is popular for professional services due to confidentiality and specialized arbitrators.

options.label: Default Courts (Per Governing Law)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in courts of the governing law jurisdiction: San Francisco (California), London (England & Wales), or Madrid (Spain).
consPartyA: May be inconvenient for one party
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the state and federal courts located in the jurisdiction of the governing law. Each Party irrevocably submits to the exclusive jurisdiction of such courts.

options.label: Delaware Courts (Neutral - US)
options.plainDescription: Disputes resolved in Delaware courts, known for sophisticated commercial law and business-friendly judiciary.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be resolved exclusively in the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware (or, if such court lacks jurisdiction, the state and federal courts located in Delaware).

options.label: JAMS Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Private arbitration under JAMS rules - popular with technology companies and professional services firms.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by binding arbitration administered by JAMS under its Comprehensive Arbitration Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator in the seat of the governing law jurisdiction.

options.label: ICC Arbitration
options.plainDescription: International arbitration under ICC rules - the gold standard for cross-border services disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator, with the seat in the capital of the governing law jurisdiction.

options.label: AAA Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Arbitration under AAA Commercial Rules - well-established with extensive arbitrator network for services disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration administered by the American Arbitration Association under its Commercial Arbitration Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by one arbitrator in the seat of the governing law jurisdiction.

options.label: LCIA Arbitration
options.plainDescription: Arbitration under LCIA rules - preferred for UK and international professional services disputes.
options.legalText: Any dispute arising from this Agreement will be finally resolved by arbitration under the LCIA Rules. The arbitration will be conducted by a sole arbitrator appointed by the LCIA Court. The seat of arbitration will be London, United Kingdom.
